{'push_id': 9707377726, 'size': 6, 'distinct_size': 1, 'ref': 'refs/heads/jmprieur/Sandbox-FutureDevEx', 'head': 'e06cb922bf1565ff3c1341496e3ed5c689f70eef', 'before': '7e4b9717569c42be61e0df76a817d11b1e2ba754', 'commits': [{'sha': 'de32b5150db4edcf13deccd5ff88c4f51737af62', 'author': {'email': 'jeferrie@microsoft.com', 'name': 'jennyf19'}, 'message': 'fix for 1707 (#1711)', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/commits/de32b5150db4edcf13deccd5ff88c4f51737af62'}, {'sha': '4370a7569277a375dc123b375f7b870e8d89bdb0', 'author': {'email': 'jeferrie@microsoft.com', 'name': 'jennyf19'}, 'message': 'changelog 1.24 (#1712)', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/commits/4370a7569277a375dc123b375f7b870e8d89bdb0'}, {'sha': '70c18be604dcea5db51200be2bb70ec7441d12f9', 'author': {'email': 'jeferrie@microsoft.com', 'name': 'jennyf19'}, 'message': 'update testing templates to 1.24 (#1713)', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/commits/70c18be604dcea5db51200be2bb70ec7441d12f9'}, {'sha': '3f4c972f28d401f77a6754c562d1939ba8f8a96a', 'author': {'email': 'jeferrie@microsoft.com', 'name': 'jennyf19'}, 'message': 'add log message for auth scheme (#1715)', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/commits/3f4c972f28d401f77a6754c562d1939ba8f8a96a'}, {'sha': '615b9734e985368ccf57671a538b70b4a3ce886c', 'author': {'email': 'Matt.Kotsenas@gmail.com', 'name': 'Matt Kotsenas'}, 'message': "Return TokenValidatedContext.Fail instead of throwing UnauthorizedAccessException in case of missing Roles / Scopes (#1717)

* Extract Roles / Scopes Jwt validation and add tests

* Refactor to remove `AllowWebApiToBeAuthorizedByACL` check from callback

Refactor to move the `AllowWebApiToBeAuthorizedByACL` check to before
the `OnTokenValidated` event chain. This is both a minor performance win
in the ACL case (possibly removing an event per token if the user
doesn't already have an event), and is a minor simplification of the
conditional logic.

As a result it's no longer easy to validate the behavior in the ACL
case; if that's deemed important we can move the whole logic set into
another helper method.

* Switch `UnauthorizedAccessException` to `TokenValidatedContext.Fail`

Today, if a token is validated, but is:

1. Missing both Scopes and Roles
2. Not authorized via ACL

Then the `JwtBearerHandler` will throw an `UnauthorizedAccessException`
that looks like this:

System.UnauthorizedAccessException: IDW10201: Neither scope or roles claim was found in the bearer token.
  at Microsoft.Identity.Web.MicrosoftIdentityWebApiAuthenticationBuilderExtensions.<>c__DisplayClass3_1.<<AddMicrosoftIdentityWebApiImplementation>b__1>d.MoveNext()
  at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.JwtBearer.JwtBearerHandler.HandleAuthenticateAsync()
  at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.JwtBearer.JwtBearerHandler.HandleAuthenticateAsync()
  at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.AuthenticationHandler`1.AuthenticateAsync()
  at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.AuthenticationService.AuthenticateAsync(HttpContext context, String scheme)
  at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.AuthenticationMiddleware.Invoke(HttpContext context)

which by default results in an unhandled exception in the auth
middleware pipeline, which in turn results in a 500 error for the user.

While one could make the argument that a 500 is appropriate in this
scenario, as the most likely cause is a misconfiguration on the AAD
side, similar types of misconfiguration, such as a missing `tid` or
`tenantId` claim results in a 401 Unauthorized error.

As a result, replacing the throw statement with a call to mark the
`ResultContext` as failed.

* Simplify confusing comment", 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/commits/615b9734e985368ccf57671a538b70b4a3ce886c'}, {'sha': 'e06cb922bf1565ff3c1341496e3ed5c689f70eef', 'author': {'email': 'jmprieur@microsoft.com', 'name': 'Jean-Marc Prieur'}, 'message': "Merge branch 'master' into jmprieur/Sandbox-FutureDevEx", 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/commits/e06cb922bf1565ff3c1341496e3ed5c689f70eef'}]}

i'm sorry for this duplicate, but i still don't understand the responses made on issue opened: [1568](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1568)

**This needs some clarification.**

I checked the example told by @jennyf19 but i don't understand how you can get a token from cache without the 2 required paramers (objectId and TenantId).

I have a similar implementation like it is described [here](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1568),  with the diference i have distributed cache with 2 levels. Memory cache and a database cache.
I have the exact same problem, when i try to retrieve an object from cache it raises the same error.
Quite doubtfull because i provide an user context which i prevously recorded while the user was subscribing to Graph.
A little more detail:
I'm saving the TenantId, ObjectId and SubscriptionId (this one for managing purposes). I do this as i said, when the user is subscribing to Graph notifications.
When i receive a callback via Lifecycle endpoint, i try to obtain an access token from cache and interact later with Microsoft Graph by injecting the access token into the GraphServiceClient class. The code breaks at the last line.

...Code simplified for brevity....
`HttpContext.User=ClaimsPrincipalFactory.FromTenantIdAndObjectId(tenantId,objectId); string[] scope=new string[]{"access_as_user"}; AuthenticationResult result=await _tokenAcquisition.GetAuthenticationResultForUserAsync(scope,tenantId,null,User);`
Is there an issue with the ClaimsPrincipalFactory class?
Or with the DI TokenAcquistion?

I opened a github issue regarding the documentation example on the ClaimsPrincipalFactory class. The example is poorly described.

i'm sorry for this duplicate, but i still don't understand the responses made on issue opened: [1568](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1568)

**This needs some clarification.**

I checked the example told by @jennyf19 but i don't understand how you can get a token from cache without the 2 required paramers (objectId and TenantId).

I have a similar implementation like it is described [here](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1568),  with the diference i have distributed cache with 2 levels. Memory cache and a database cache.
I have the exact same problem, when i try to retrieve an object from cache it raises the same error.
Quite doubtfull because i provide an user context which i prevously recorded while the user was subscribing to Graph.
A little more detail:
I'm saving the TenantId, ObjectId and SubscriptionId (this one for managing purposes). I do this as i said, when the user is subscribing to Graph notifications.
When i receive a callback via Lifecycle endpoint, i try to obtain an access token from cache and interact later with Microsoft Graph by injecting the access token into the GraphServiceClient class. The code breaks at the last line.

...Code simplified for brevity....
`HttpContext.User=ClaimsPrincipalFactory.FromTenantIdAndObjectId(tenantId,objectId); string[] scope=new string[]{"access_as_user"}; AuthenticationResult result=await _tokenAcquisition.GetAuthenticationResultForUserAsync(scope,tenantId,null,User);`
Is there an issue with the ClaimsPrincipalFactory class?
Or with the DI TokenAcquistion?

I opened a github issue regarding the documentation example on the ClaimsPrincipalFactory class. The example is poorly described.

* Introduce `IMicrosoftIdentityAuthenticationDelegatingHandlerFactory`

Currently, it's very difficult to customize the behavior of the
`DelegatingHandler` classes that add the auth token, as the
`DownstreamWebApiExtensions` `new()` up the handlers directly.

Ideally I would register the handlers in the `IServiceCollection`
directly, and then resolve it from the container, however in the case of
multiple downstream APIs we need to resolve the correct named
configuration from the `IOptionsMonitor`, and I'm not aware of a way to
do that with just the dependency injection abstraction APIs.

As a result, I've instead introduced a public factory interface that
takes the `IServiceProvider` and the configuration name, which then
allows for creating the handler from the factory class. Users that want
to customize the handlers can then replace the
`IMicrosoftIdentityAuthenticationDelegatingHandlerFactory` registration
with a class that creates their own implementations.

* Add test to validate overriding HTTP handler behavior

* Remove IServiceProvider from IMicrosoftIdentityAuthenticationDelegatingHandlerFactory signature and rely on constructor injection in the implementation instead

* Rename `DefaultMicrosoftIdentityAuthenticationDelegatingHandlerFactory`

Add `Default` prefix to the handler factory, make it `internal` and
split the interface and the implementation into separate files since the
naming scheme may make them harder to locate in the same file

* Move common configuration to private Core method

* Fix spelling error", 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/commits/7e02045e6718e9a1e24eba7fca21c3d05c804d83'}, {'sha': '35efa57e4e0b0a4ef779b66f48c908194d776ec0', 'author': {'email': 'jeferrie@microsoft.com', 'name': 'jennyf19'}, 'message': 'fix param name (#1679)', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/commits/35efa57e4e0b0a4ef779b66f48c908194d776ec0'}, {'sha': '9b0ebb70f1fc4f6d5564f4fc9754503f2a001044', 'author': {'email': 'jmprieur@microsoft.com', 'name': 'Jean-Marc Prieur'}, 'message': 'Updates the HomeB2CController to align with changes in the (#1680)

### Description of the issue
<!-- Describe the issue in detail here -->
I want to use the command `msidentity-app-sync` to provision MS Identity auth in a .NET Core webapi project generated with the command `dotnet new webapi -au SingleOrg`.
I have an existing AAD app registration with app ID `f9ff8c4f-2a57-44c8-bf37-c4df29f5b712`.
The output from the tool indicates a new app registration was created, instead of using the one with the provided ID:

```
msidentity-app-sync --tenant-id $tenantID --client-id f9ff8c4f-2a57-44c8-bf37-c4df29f5b712
Detected project type dotnet-webapi.
Authentication is not enabled yet in this project. An app registration will be created, but the tool does not add the code yet (work in progress).
Created app 9b767f36-0867-452d-b119-4440b97976a3. Summary
Writing the project AppId = 9b767f36-0867-452d-b119-4440b97976a3
```

I may not be forming the command correctly, as the `msidentity-app-sync --help` text suggests passing another argument in addition to `--client-id`, but omits the name:
>  You might want to also pass-in the ?? if you know it.

The document linked above indicates this argument is `--tenant-id`, although it did not succeed in updating my existing app registration. 

Am I missing an argument to this command? 'created_at': '2020-09-30T13:39:39Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-14T15:40:53Z', 'closed_at': '2020-10-02T14:59:22Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
DI should always use interfaces and not classes. Existing projects that have their constructors designed to depend on IGraphServiceClient currently fail to be properly constructed by .NET Core's DI as AddMicrosoftGraph() registers GraphServiceClient instead of the interface

**Describe the solution you'd like**
In Microsoft.Identity.Web.MicrosoftGraphExtensions::AddMicrosoftGraph replace 
builder.Services.AddScoped<GraphServiceClient, GraphServiceClient>(serviceProvider =>
with
builder.Services.AddScoped<**I**GraphServiceClient, GraphServiceClient>(serviceProvider =>

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Alternatively, the registered GraphServiceClient needs to be obtained by constructing an intermediate ServiceProvider and the necessary classes manually instantiated.

'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'Adding generation of accessors for claims independently of AAD token version of the token
See #1800

## Developer experience:

1. Add a using:
   ```CSharp
   using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt,
   ```

2.  In the code, on a ClaimsPrincipal or an IdentityPrincipal instance, you will get access to extension methods that retrieve the claims in the instance independently of them being long or short claims (which depends on the token version: v1.0 or v2.0 tokens). Developers will also get completion telling them if the claim is safe or not for use in authorization policies, and what privacy category they belong to
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13203188/160029772-1377405f-1a02-4c4a-9af4-0d42ab233f0a.png)

See also the description of the accessors:

[ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/Microsoft.IdentityModel.Aad/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)

## Design
This PR a bit different from others: It uses code generation
The claims are described in **ClaimsKnowledge.tti** (Text Template Include file)
This include file is included in:
-  **ClaimTypeMapping.tt**, which generates ClaimTypeMapping.cs (which was already existing), 
-  **ClaimsTypeAccessor.tt**, which generates **ClaimsTypeAccessor.gen.cs**, which contains a partial class implementation of `ClaimsTypeAccessor`, the other partial being in **ClaimsTypeAccessor.cs**
- **ClaimsAccessorDoc.tt**, which generates [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)', 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'Adding generation of accessors for claims independently of AAD token version of the token
See #1800

## Developer experience:

1. Add a using:
   ```CSharp
   using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt,
   ```

2.  In the code, on a ClaimsPrincipal or an IdentityPrincipal instance, you will get access to extension methods that retrieve the claims in the instance independently of them being long or short claims (which depends on the token version: v1.0 or v2.0 tokens). Developers will also get completion telling them if the claim is safe or not for use in authorization policies, and what privacy category they belong to
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13203188/160029772-1377405f-1a02-4c4a-9af4-0d42ab233f0a.png)

See also the description of the accessors:

[ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/Microsoft.IdentityModel.Aad/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)

## Design
This PR a bit different from others: It uses code generation
The claims are described in **ClaimsKnowledge.tti** (Text Template Include file)
This include file is included in:
-  **ClaimTypeMapping.tt**, which generates ClaimTypeMapping.cs (which was already existing), 
-  **ClaimsTypeAccessor.tt**, which generates **ClaimsTypeAccessor.gen.cs**, which contains a partial class implementation of `ClaimsTypeAccessor`, the other partial being in **ClaimsTypeAccessor.cs**
- **ClaimsAccessorDoc.tt**, which generates [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)', 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'Adding generation of accessors for claims independently of AAD token version of the token
See #1800

## Developer experience:

1. Add a using:
   ```CSharp
   using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt,
   ```

2.  In the code, on a ClaimsPrincipal or an IdentityPrincipal instance, you will get access to extension methods that retrieve the claims in the instance independently of them being long or short claims (which depends on the token version: v1.0 or v2.0 tokens). Developers will also get completion telling them if the claim is safe or not for use in authorization policies, and what privacy category they belong to
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13203188/160029772-1377405f-1a02-4c4a-9af4-0d42ab233f0a.png)

See also the description of the accessors:

[ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/Microsoft.IdentityModel.Aad/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)

## Design
This PR a bit different from others: It uses code generation
The claims are described in **ClaimsKnowledge.tti** (Text Template Include file)
This include file is included in:
-  **ClaimTypeMapping.tt**, which generates ClaimTypeMapping.cs (which was already existing), 
-  **ClaimsTypeAccessor.tt**, which generates **ClaimsTypeAccessor.gen.cs**, which contains a partial class implementation of `ClaimsTypeAccessor`, the other partial being in **ClaimsTypeAccessor.cs**
- **ClaimsAccessorDoc.tt**, which generates [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)', 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'Adding generation of accessors for claims independently of AAD token version of the token
See #1800

## Developer experience:

1. Add a using:
   ```CSharp
   using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt,
   ```

2.  In the code, on a ClaimsPrincipal or an IdentityPrincipal instance, you will get access to extension methods that retrieve the claims in the instance independently of them being long or short claims (which depends on the token version: v1.0 or v2.0 tokens). Developers will also get completion telling them if the claim is safe or not for use in authorization policies, and what privacy category they belong to
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13203188/160029772-1377405f-1a02-4c4a-9af4-0d42ab233f0a.png)

See also the description of the accessors:

[ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/Microsoft.IdentityModel.Aad/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)

## Design
This PR a bit different from others: It uses code generation
The claims are described in **ClaimsKnowledge.tti** (Text Template Include file)
This include file is included in:
-  **ClaimTypeMapping.tt**, which generates ClaimTypeMapping.cs (which was already existing), 
-  **ClaimsTypeAccessor.tt**, which generates **ClaimsTypeAccessor.gen.cs**, which contains a partial class implementation of `ClaimsTypeAccessor`, the other partial being in **ClaimsTypeAccessor.cs**
- **ClaimsAccessorDoc.tt**, which generates [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Which version of Microsoft Identity Web are you using?**  11.16.0
Note that to get help, you need to run the latest version. 
<!-- E.g. Microsoft Identity Web 1.0.0-preview -->

**Where is the issue?**
* Web app
    * [ ] Sign-in users
    * [ ] Sign-in users and call web APIs
* Web API
    * [ ] Protected web APIs (validating tokens)
    * [ ] Protected web APIs (validating scopes)
    * [x] Protected web APIs call downstream web APIs

     * [ ] In-memory caches
     * [ ] Session caches
     * [ ] Distributed caches

**Is this a new or an existing app?**
<!-- Ex:
a. The app is in production and I have upgraded to a new version of Microsoft Identity Web.
b. The app is in production and I haven't upgraded Microsoft Identity Web, but started seeing this issue.
c. This is a new app or an experiment.
-->
Those are new apps for experiments

**Repro**

I have two apps registered within Azure AD that support both multitenant and personal accounts (**external** and **internal**)
For external, the API Permission is set for the internal app so it can downstream the user information within the token.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25317691/159719705-7c61c93d-edb2-4c1c-83ac-2073d50e28b8.png)

I'm using Postman for testing calling internal from external on behave of the identified user.
I'm retrieving access tokens using the Authorization tab

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25317691/159723081-9bad7b86-ca81-42d8-b9c1-05c5f1550b53.png)

where for the scope I provide the one registered for external, as using '.default' returns invalid_scope from Postman.
When I try to call
```csharp
string accessToken = await _tokenAcquisition.GetAccessTokenForUserAsync(_scopesToAccessDownstreamApi);
```
with either '.default' scope or one registered for internal in `_scopesToAccessDownstreamApi` I receive the exception (I'm using the Application ID URI of internal for those scopes)

**Expected behavior**
Code should work despite supported account types for which the app is registered.

**Actual behavior**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25317691/159723933-c2fa327a-3b0e-4346-89bf-4dd407fbb014.png)

**Possible solution**
<!--- Only if you have suggestions on a fix for the bug. -->

**Additional context / logs / screenshots / link to code**
<!-- Please do not include any customer data or Personal Identifiable Information (PII) in any content posted to GitHub. See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/compliance/regulatory/gdpr#gdpr-faqs for more info on PII.-->
The same code works when I use single-tenant registered apps. The only difference is in "TennantId" at appsettings.json where for this case it is set to 'common', also the URLs for authorize and token at Postman have TennantId instead of common.

The same issue is for apps registered to support only personal accounts so I'm assuming there is some issue related to provisioning the access to downstream API for tokens generated for personal accounts. 
Additionally, for those apps, I'm not able to change the status to granted, even though I'm logged in as Global Administrator.

'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'Adding generation of accessors for claims independently of AAD token version of the token
See #1800

## Developer experience:

1. Add a using:
   ```CSharp
   using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt,
   ```

2.  In the code, on a ClaimsPrincipal or an IdentityPrincipal instance, you will get access to extension methods that retrieve the claims in the instance independently of them being long or short claims (which depends on the token version: v1.0 or v2.0 tokens). Developers will also get completion telling them if the claim is safe or not for use in authorization policies, and what privacy category they belong to
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13203188/160029772-1377405f-1a02-4c4a-9af4-0d42ab233f0a.png)

See also the description of the accessors:

[ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/Microsoft.IdentityModel.Aad/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)

## Design
This PR a bit different from others: It uses code generation
The claims are described in **ClaimsKnowledge.tti** (Text Template Include file)
This include file is included in:
-  **ClaimTypeMapping.tt**, which generates ClaimTypeMapping.cs (which was already existing), 
-  **ClaimsTypeAccessor.tt**, which generates **ClaimsTypeAccessor.gen.cs**, which contains a partial class implementation of `ClaimsTypeAccessor`, the other partial being in **ClaimsTypeAccessor.cs**
- **ClaimsAccessorDoc.tt**, which generates [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)', 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'Adding generation of accessors for claims independently of AAD token version of the token
See #1800

## Developer experience:

1. Add a using:
   ```CSharp
   using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt,
   ```

2.  In the code, on a ClaimsPrincipal or an IdentityPrincipal instance, you will get access to extension methods that retrieve the claims in the instance independently of them being long or short claims (which depends on the token version: v1.0 or v2.0 tokens). Developers will also get completion telling them if the claim is safe or not for use in authorization policies, and what privacy category they belong to
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13203188/160029772-1377405f-1a02-4c4a-9af4-0d42ab233f0a.png)

See also the description of the accessors:

[ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/Microsoft.IdentityModel.Aad/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)

## Design
This PR a bit different from others: It uses code generation
The claims are described in **ClaimsKnowledge.tti** (Text Template Include file)
This include file is included in:
-  **ClaimTypeMapping.tt**, which generates ClaimTypeMapping.cs (which was already existing), 
-  **ClaimsTypeAccessor.tt**, which generates **ClaimsTypeAccessor.gen.cs**, which contains a partial class implementation of `ClaimsTypeAccessor`, the other partial being in **ClaimsTypeAccessor.cs**
- **ClaimsAccessorDoc.tt**, which generates [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)', 'author_association': 'MEMBER', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "**Which version of Microsoft Identity Web are you using?**
master

**Where is the issue?**
Certificate doesn't load, and user is not informed.

To Repo
1. put a certificate that has expired into the local cert store.
2. populate a CertificateDescription that has the coordinates to the certificate in the local store.
3. call DefaultCertificateLoader.LoadIfNeeded()

The load will fail because of [this line](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/blob/9b159ba02f3b38d62777ed21b71704dfd84e538d/src/Microsoft.Identity.Web.Certificate/DefaultCertificateLoader.cs#L325).
One could argue, why are you filtering by default.
It would be helpful to have a property on CertificateDescription to filter.
Anyone that calls 'LoadIfNeeded' would expect it to succeed, since there is no return value.
Users that subsequently use the cert, could have a null ref, etc.

I think it would be good to throw here.

", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1700/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1700/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/comments/1095939123', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1700#issuecomment-1095939123', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1700', 'id': 1095939123, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDODmEq2c5BUrQz', 'user': {'login': 'jmprieur', 'id': 13203188, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEzMjAzMTg4', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/13203188?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jmprieur', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-04-12T03:41:14Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-12T03:41:14Z', 'author_association': 'COLLABORATOR', 'body': "Thanks @brentschmaltz 
This would be a breaking change. And the whole retry model is based on this. 
I don't think we'll take this one.

'comments': 1, 'created_at': '2022-04-07T22:30:15Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-08T00:36:22Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'I've implemented ```[Authorize]``` before using ADFS, so have some experience with what is happening.

Implemented according to the page.

Added to Startup.cs
```c#
public void ConfigureServices(IServiceCollection services)
{
    services.AddMicrosoftIdentityWebApiAuthentication(Configuration, "AzureAd");
```

Added to appsettings.json
```json
{
  "AzureAd": {
    "Instance": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/",
    "TenantId": "c53<guid>c81",
    "ClientId": "96c<guid>e3f"
  },
  "Logging": {
    "LogLevel": {
      "Default": "Information",
      "Microsoft": "Warning",
      "Microsoft.Hosting.Lifetime": "Information"
    }
  },
  "AllowedHosts": "*"
}
```

Got an invalid Audience error and so tried adding:
```json
"Audience": "api://96c<guid>e3f"
```
and this:
```json
"Audience": "//96c<guid>e3f"
```

Adding an audience and modifying the clientid both got rid of the error message.   But, I'm still getting 401 when calling method with an Authorization header and specifying a valid "Bearer <token>" value.  Without anything in the logs, tricky to troubleshoot.  Everything looks good as far as I know, so how to troubleshoot?

Add this in the past helped, but didn't seem to do anything this time:
```c#
IdentityModelEventSource.ShowPII = true;
```

I suspect many reading this article might want to enable some troubleshooting output.  Possibly update article with how to enable some troubleshooting output or a link to troubleshoot?


---

+﻿<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
+  <PropertyGroup>
+
+    <!--This should be passed from the VSTS build-->
+    <ClientSemVer Condition="'$(ClientSemVer)' == ''">1.0.0-localbuild</ClientSemVer>
+    <!--This will generate AssemblyVersion, AssemblyFileVersion and AssemblyInformationVersion-->
+    <Version>$(ClientSemVer)</Version>
+
+    <DefineConstants>$(DefineConstants);WEB</DefineConstants>
+    <PackageRequireLicenseAcceptance>true</PackageRequireLicenseAcceptance>
+    <!-- Copyright needs to be in the form of © not (c) to be compliant -->
+    <Title>Microsoft Identity Web Identity Federation</Title>
+    <Authors>Microsoft</Authors>
+    <Company>Microsoft Corporation</Company>
+    <Product>Microsoft Identity Web Identity Federation</Product>
+    <Description>
+      This package brings Identity Federation management.
+    </Description>
+    <Copyright>© Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.</Copyright>
+    <PackageLicenseExpression>MIT</PackageLicenseExpression>
+    <PackageProjectUrl>https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web</PackageProjectUrl>
+    <RepositoryUrl>https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web</RepositoryUrl>
+    <PackageReleaseNotes>The release notes are available at https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/releases and the roadmap at https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/wiki#roadmap </PackageReleaseNotes>
+    <PackageTags>Microsoft Identity Web;Microsoft identity platform;Microsoft.Identity.Web;.NET;ASP.NET Core;Web App;Web API;B2C;Azure Active Directory;AAD;Identity;Authentication;Authorization;Identity Federation</PackageTags>
+  </PropertyGroup>
+  <PropertyGroup Label="Source Link">
+    <PublishRepositoryUrl>true</PublishRepositoryUrl>
+    <EmbedUntrackedSources>true</EmbedUntrackedSources>
+    <!-- Build symbol package (.snupkg) to distribute the PDB containing Source Link -->
+    <IncludeSymbols>true</IncludeSymbols>
+    <SymbolPackageFormat>snupkg</SymbolPackageFormat>
+  </PropertyGroup>
+
+  <ItemGroup>
+    <AdditionalFiles Include="..\..\stylecop.json" />
+  </ItemGroup>
+
+  <ItemGroup>
+    <AdditionalFiles Include="..\..\.sonarlint\azuread_microsoft-identity-web\CSharp\SonarLint.xml" Link="SonarLint.xml" />
+  </ItemGroup>
+
+  <ItemGroup>
+    <None Include="..\..\LICENSE">
+      <Pack>True</Pack>
+      <PackagePath></PackagePath>
+    </None>
+  </ItemGroup>
+
+  <ItemGroup Label="Build Tools" Condition="$([MSBuild]::IsOsPlatform('Windows'))">
+    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.SourceLink.GitHub" Version="1.0.0" PrivateAssets="All" />
+  </ItemGroup>
+

+﻿<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
+  <PropertyGroup>
+
+    <!--This should be passed from the VSTS build-->
+    <ClientSemVer Condition="'$(ClientSemVer)' == ''">1.0.0-localbuild</ClientSemVer>
+    <!--This will generate AssemblyVersion, AssemblyFileVersion and AssemblyInformationVersion-->
+    <Version>$(ClientSemVer)</Version>
+
+    <DefineConstants>$(DefineConstants);WEB</DefineConstants>
+    <PackageRequireLicenseAcceptance>true</PackageRequireLicenseAcceptance>
+    <!-- Copyright needs to be in the form of © not (c) to be compliant -->
+    <Title>Microsoft Identity Web Identity Federation</Title>
+    <Authors>Microsoft</Authors>
+    <Company>Microsoft Corporation</Company>
+    <Product>Microsoft Identity Web Identity Federation</Product>
+    <Description>
+      This package brings Identity Federation management.
+    </Description>
+    <Copyright>© Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.</Copyright>
+    <PackageLicenseExpression>MIT</PackageLicenseExpression>
+    <PackageProjectUrl>https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web</PackageProjectUrl>
+    <RepositoryUrl>https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web</RepositoryUrl>
+    <PackageReleaseNotes>The release notes are available at https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/releases and the roadmap at https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/wiki#roadmap </PackageReleaseNotes>
+    <PackageTags>Microsoft Identity Web;Microsoft identity platform;Microsoft.Identity.Web;.NET;ASP.NET Core;Web App;Web API;B2C;Azure Active Directory;AAD;Identity;Authentication;Authorization;Identity Federation</PackageTags>
+  </PropertyGroup>
+  <PropertyGroup Label="Source Link">
+    <PublishRepositoryUrl>true</PublishRepositoryUrl>
+    <EmbedUntrackedSources>true</EmbedUntrackedSources>
+    <!-- Build symbol package (.snupkg) to distribute the PDB containing Source Link -->
+    <IncludeSymbols>true</IncludeSymbols>
+    <SymbolPackageFormat>snupkg</SymbolPackageFormat>
+  </PropertyGroup>
+
+  <ItemGroup>
+    <AdditionalFiles Include="..\..\stylecop.json" />
+  </ItemGroup>
+
+  <ItemGroup>
+    <AdditionalFiles Include="..\..\.sonarlint\azuread_microsoft-identity-web\CSharp\SonarLint.xml" Link="SonarLint.xml" />
+  </ItemGroup>
+
+  <ItemGroup>
+    <None Include="..\..\LICENSE">
+      <Pack>True</Pack>
+      <PackagePath></PackagePath>
+    </None>
+  </ItemGroup>
+
+  <ItemGroup Label="Build Tools" Condition="$([MSBuild]::IsOsPlatform('Windows'))">
+    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.SourceLink.GitHub" Version="1.0.0" PrivateAssets="All" />
+  </ItemGroup>
+
+  <PropertyGroup>
+    <TargetFrameworks>netcoreapp3.1; net462; net472; net5.0; netstandard2.0</TargetFrameworks>
+    <SignAssembly>true</SignAssembly>
+    <AssemblyOriginatorKeyFile>../../build/MSAL.snk</AssemblyOriginatorKeyFile>
+    <GenerateDocumentationFile>true</GenerateDocumentationFile>
+    <Nullable>enable</Nullable>
+  </PropertyGroup>

'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'Adding generation of accessors for claims independently of AAD token version of the token
See #1800

## Developer experience:

1. Add a using:
   ```CSharp
   using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt,
   ```

2.  In the code, on a ClaimsPrincipal or an IdentityPrincipal instance, you will get access to extension methods that retrieve the claims in the instance independently of them being long or short claims (which depends on the token version: v1.0 or v2.0 tokens). Developers will also get completion telling them if the claim is safe or not for use in authorization policies, and what privacy category they belong to
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13203188/160029772-1377405f-1a02-4c4a-9af4-0d42ab233f0a.png)

See also the description of the accessors:

[ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/Microsoft.IdentityModel.Aad/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)

## Design
This PR a bit different from others: It uses code generation
The claims are described in **ClaimsKnowledge.tti** (Text Template Include file)
This include file is included in:
-  **ClaimTypeMapping.tt**, which generates ClaimTypeMapping.cs (which was already existing), 
-  **ClaimsTypeAccessor.tt**, which generates **ClaimsTypeAccessor.gen.cs**, which contains a partial class implementation of `ClaimsTypeAccessor`, the other partial being in **ClaimsTypeAccessor.cs**
- **ClaimsAccessorDoc.tt**, which generates [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)', 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'Adding generation of accessors for claims independently of AAD token version of the token
See #1800

## Developer experience:

1. Add a using:
   ```CSharp
   using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt,
   ```

2.  In the code, on a ClaimsPrincipal or an IdentityPrincipal instance, you will get access to extension methods that retrieve the claims in the instance independently of them being long or short claims (which depends on the token version: v1.0 or v2.0 tokens). Developers will also get completion telling them if the claim is safe or not for use in authorization policies, and what privacy category they belong to
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13203188/160029772-1377405f-1a02-4c4a-9af4-0d42ab233f0a.png)

See also the description of the accessors:

[ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/Microsoft.IdentityModel.Aad/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)

## Design
This PR a bit different from others: It uses code generation
The claims are described in **ClaimsKnowledge.tti** (Text Template Include file)
This include file is included in:
-  **ClaimTypeMapping.tt**, which generates ClaimTypeMapping.cs (which was already existing), 
-  **ClaimsTypeAccessor.tt**, which generates **ClaimsTypeAccessor.gen.cs**, which contains a partial class implementation of `ClaimsTypeAccessor`, the other partial being in **ClaimsTypeAccessor.cs**
- **ClaimsAccessorDoc.tt**, which generates [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'COLLABORATOR', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "from @onovotny and copied from https://github.com/Azure-Samples/active-directory-aspnetcore-webapp-openidconnect-v2/issues/240

In the Microsoft.Identity.Web library, the system should automatically clear (`RejectPrincipal()`) the auth cookie if the corresponding account entry is missing from the token cache. This can happen if the cache expired, if it was a memory cache and the server bounced, etc.

The issue is that the system is now in an inconsistent state, where the user is considered logged-in, but any operations to call API's won't succeed because there's no token cache, no refresh token, etc.

I've worked around this here: https://github.com/dotnet-foundation/membership

In order to do so, I had to make some changes to `ITokenAquisition` and the MsalAbstractCacheProvider's GetCacheKey method.

`ITokenAcquisition` needed a method to check for a user's token cache:
https://github.com/dotnet-foundation/membership/blob/97b75e30e50aab76bfa5a21f1ab88bf31ae66da4/Microsoft.Identity.Web/TokenAcquisition.cs#L406-L426

In there, it takes the `CookieValidatePrincipalContext` to get the incoming ClaimsPrincpal as HtttpContext.User is not yet set at that point. It stores it in the HttpContext.Items via the `StoreCookieValidatePrincipalContext` extension method (used later by the GetCacheKey method so it can derive the appropriate key): 
https://github.com/dotnet-foundation/membership/blob/97b75e30e50aab76bfa5a21f1ab88bf31ae66da4/Microsoft.Identity.Web/TokenCacheProviders/MsalAbstractTokenCacheProvider.cs#L68-L69

Finally, the `CookieAuthenticationOptions` needs to be configured to check for and reject the incoming principal (this could/should be moved into the main IdentityPlatform AddMsal extension methods):
https://github.com/dotnet-foundation/membership/blob/97b75e30e50aab76bfa5a21f1ab88bf31ae66da4/Membership/Startup.cs#L110-L123

I can submit these changes as PR if you're in agreement with these changes.", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/13/reactions', 'total_count': 10, '+1': 10, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/13/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/comments/1090508512', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/13#issuecomment-1090508512', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/13', 'id': 1090508512, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDODmEq2c5A_9bg', 'user': {'login': 'jmprieur', 'id': 13203188, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEzMjAzMTg4', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/13203188?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jmprieur', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-04-06T17:12:24Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-06T17:12:24Z', 'author_association': 'COLLABORATOR', 'body': '@bgavrilMS @pmaytak : when can this happen? `MsalClientException: The cache contains multiple tokens satisfying the requirements. Currently we are doing unnecessary/moot calls to `AddTokenAcqusition` within `EnableTokenAcquisitionToCallDownstreamApi` if we have Singleton Services depending on Token Acquisition.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Allow controlling whether we want Singleton or Scoped Token Acquisition when calling `EnableTokenAcquisitionToCallDownstreamApi`. This can happen either through a configuration/appsettings or through a parameter directly on `EnableTokenAcquisitionToCallDownstreamApi`.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
A current alternative/workaround is to call `AddTokenAcquisition(true)` after calling `EnableTokenAcquisitionToCallDownstreamApi`, but that results in unnecessary work adding/removing the existing Token Acquisition which was created with the wrong lifetime.

'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/MattKotsenas/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': "Currently, it's very difficult to customize the behavior of the
`DelegatingHandler` classes that add the auth token, as the
`DownstreamWebApiExtensions` `new()` up the handlers directly.

Ideally I would register the handlers in the `IServiceCollection`
directly, and then resolve it from the container, however in the case of
multiple downstream APIs we need to resolve the correct named
configuration from the `IOptionsMonitor`, and I'm not aware of a way to
do that with just the dependency injection abstraction APIs.

As a result, I've instead introduced a public factory interface that
takes the configuration name, which then
allows for creating the handler from the factory class. Users that want
to customize the handlers can then register their own
`IMicrosoftIdentityAuthenticationDelegatingHandlerFactory` 
that creates their own handlers.", 'created_at': '2022-03-28T19:49:57Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-31T16:30:06Z', 'closed_at': None, 'merged_at': None, 'merge_commit_sha': 'body': "Currently, it's very difficult to customize the behavior of the
`DelegatingHandler` classes that add the auth token, as the
`DownstreamWebApiExtensions` `new()` up the handlers directly.

Ideally I would register the handlers in the `IServiceCollection`
directly, and then resolve it from the container, however in the case of
multiple downstream APIs we need to resolve the correct named
configuration from the `IOptionsMonitor`, and I'm not aware of a way to
do that with just the dependency injection abstraction APIs.

As a result, I've instead introduced a public factory interface that
takes the configuration name, which then
allows for creating the handler from the factory class. Users that want
to customize the handlers can then register their own
`IMicrosoftIdentityAuthenticationDelegatingHandlerFactory` 
that creates their own handlers.", 'created_at': '2022-03-28T19:49:57Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-31T16:30:06Z', 'closed_at': None, 'merged_at': None, 'merge_commit_sha': 'body': "Currently, it's very difficult to customize the behavior of the
`DelegatingHandler` classes that add the auth token, as the
`DownstreamWebApiExtensions` `new()` up the handlers directly.

Ideally I would register the handlers in the `IServiceCollection`
directly, and then resolve it from the container, however in the case of
multiple downstream APIs we need to resolve the correct named
configuration from the `IOptionsMonitor`, and I'm not aware of a way to
do that with just the dependency injection abstraction APIs.

As a result, I've instead introduced a public factory interface that
takes the configuration name, which then
allows for creating the handler from the factory class. Users that want
to customize the handlers can then register their own
`IMicrosoftIdentityAuthenticationDelegatingHandlerFactory` 
that creates their own handlers.", 'created_at': '2022-03-28T19:49:57Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-31T16:30:06Z', 'closed_at': None, 'merged_at': None, 'merge_commit_sha': **Which version of MSAL.NET are you using?**
<!-- Ex: MSAL.NET 4.30.0 -->
4.42.0
**Platform**
<!-- Ex: .NET 4.5, .NET Core, UWP, Xamarin Android, Xamarin iOS -->
.net core

**What authentication flow has the issue?**
* Desktop / Mobile
    * [ ] Interactive
    * [ ] Integrated Windows Authentication
    * [ ] Username Password
    * [ ] Device code flow (browserless)
* Web app 
    * [ ] Authorization code
    * [X] On-Behalf-Of
* Daemon app

Other?
<!-- Please describe here -->

**Is this a new or existing app?**
<!-- Ex:
a. The app is in production, and I have upgraded to a new version of MSAL.
b. The app is in production, I haven't upgraded MSAL, but started seeing this issue.
c. This is a new app or experiment.
-->
This app is in production, I am adding new feature to it.

**Repro**
1. iniialize redis token cache 
2. call AcquireTokenInLongRunningProcess api , token is created in redis
3. call IConfidentialClientApplication.RemoveAsync to remove this user
4. call  IConfidentialClientApplication.GetAccountsAsync, the account is deleted
5. the token is redis is not deleted.
```csharp
var externalResourceToken = await longRunningWebApi.InitiateLongRunningProcessInWebApi(scopes, token, ref sessionKey)
                        .WithAuthority(authority)
                        .WithSendX5C(true)
                        .ExecuteAsync()
                        .ConfigureAwait(false);
await this.confidentialClientApplication.RemoveAsync(externalResourceToken.Account);
```
all code run successfully.
after this call, the redis key still exist.

**Expected behavior**
the redis key should be removed.
**Actual behavior**
the redis kye still exist.
**Possible solution**
<!--- Only if you have suggestions on a fix for the bug -->

'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Which version of Microsoft Identity Web are you using?**
Microsoft Identity Web 1.16.0 and Microsoft Identity Web 1.16.1

**Where is the issue?**
When calling await _graphServiceClient.Users["username"].Request().GetAsync();
With 1.16.0 Get Null Reference Exception
With 1.16.1 Get MsalUiRequiredException

* Web API
    * [ ] Protected web APIs (validating tokens)
    * [ ] Protected web APIs (validating scopes)
    * [ X] Protected web APIs call downstream web APIs
* Token cache serialization
     * [X ] In-memory caches
     * [ ] Session caches
     * [ ] Distributed caches

**Is this a new or an existing app?**
This app is currently in production using .NET Core 2.2.  Working on upgrading to .NET 5.0, updating the libraries and now running into this issue.

**Repro**

Service configuration:
```csharp
services.AddMicrosoftIdentityWebApiAuthentication(configuration)
                .EnableTokenAcquisitionToCallDownstreamApi()
                .AddMicrosoftGraph(configuration.GetSection("MicrosoftGraph"))
                .AddInMemoryTokenCaches();
```

appsettings.json:
```csharp
"AzureAd": {
    "ClientId": "xxx.xxx......",
    "Domain": "domain.com",
    "Instance": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/",
    "TenantId": "xxxxxx......",
    "ClientSecret": "xxxxxxxxx...."
  },
  "MicrosoftGraph": {
    "BaseUrl": "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0",
    "Scopes": "user.read user.read.all"
  },
```
Usage of MS Graph
```csharp
var user = await _graphServiceClient.Users["username"].Request().GetAsync();
```
**Expected behavior**
Get the requested user details

**Actual behavior**
The exceptions mentioned above are thrown instead of getting the user details

**Additional context / logs / screenshots**

'2022-03-28T16:14:14Z', 'closed_at': '2022-03-28T06:28:05Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Hello,
we are using in our projects the latest version of Microsoft.Identity.Web. We came to an interesting challenge that I am not sure how to solve properly. Maybe you could point me in the right direction.

We are using Microsoft.Identity.Web and the IDistributedCache implementation for L2 cache targeting environment X. 
In the same project, we are using a different library that also requires an implementation of the IDistributedCache interface but with the requirement to target a different L2 cache environment Y.

Is there a way for me to pass an instance of L2 cache to Microsoft.Identity.Web without using the IDistributedCache interface? Maybe there might be a way to do it directly in the constructor AddDistributedTokenCaches() by passing some singletons? Are there other ways to register a custom L2 cache in Microsoft.Identity.Web?

And the last question related to caching. Is there a way to specify a custom implementation of L1 cache?

Thank you for your feedback,
Patrick', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1670/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': Hope this is the right place to ask a question. I'm a little lost here.

I have deployed an ASP.NET Core Web API to an Azure App Service, and given that App Service its own system-assigned managed identity.

I have granted User.Read.All and Directory.Read.All Graph application permissions to the system identity service principal.

What do I need to do to make Microsoft.Identity.Web.MicrosoftGraph use my system managed identity when calling Graph? I have this in my Program.cs:

```
builder.Services.AddAuthentication(JwtBearerDefaults.AuthenticationScheme)
    .AddMicrosoftIdentityWebApi(builder.Configuration.GetSection("AzureAd"))
    .EnableTokenAcquisitionToCallDownstreamApi()
    .AddMicrosoftGraphAppOnly(auth => new Microsoft.Graph.GraphServiceClient(auth))
    .AddInMemoryTokenCaches();
```

... and my appsettings.json has an AzureAd section like this:

```
  "AzureAd": {
    "Instance": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/",
    "Domain": "<my org>.onmicrosoft.com",
    "TenantId": "<my org's tenant id>",
    "ClientId": "<my app registration client id>",
    "Scopes": "access_as_user",
    "CallbackPath": "/signin-oidc"
  },
```

Should it "just work", or is there some extra step I'm missing? Or are system-assigned MSIs not supported? I've seen a reference in the code to a `UserAssignedManagedIdentityClientId` option, but I've tried setting that to a few different values with no success.

Cheers,

'**Which version of Microsoft Identity Web are you using?**  11.16.0
Note that to get help, you need to run the latest version. 
<!-- E.g. Microsoft Identity Web 1.0.0-preview -->

**Where is the issue?**
* Web app
    * [ ] Sign-in users
    * [ ] Sign-in users and call web APIs
* Web API
    * [ ] Protected web APIs (validating tokens)
    * [ ] Protected web APIs (validating scopes)
    * [x] Protected web APIs call downstream web APIs
* Token cache serialization
     * [ ] In-memory caches
     * [ ] Session caches
     * [ ] Distributed caches
* Other (please describe)

**Is this a new or an existing app?**
<!-- Ex:
a. The app is in production and I have upgraded to a new version of Microsoft Identity Web.
b. The app is in production and I haven't upgraded Microsoft Identity Web, but started seeing this issue.
c. This is a new app or an experiment.
-->
Those are new apps for experiments

**Repro**

I have two apps registered within Azure AD that support both multitenant and personal accounts (**external** and **internal**)
For external, the API Permission is set for the internal app so it can downstream the user information within the token.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25317691/159719705-7c61c93d-edb2-4c1c-83ac-2073d50e28b8.png)

I'm using Postman for testing calling internal from external on behave of the identified user.
I'm retrieving access tokens using the Authorization tab

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25317691/159723081-9bad7b86-ca81-42d8-b9c1-05c5f1550b53.png)

where for the scope I provide the one registered for external, as using '.default' returns invalid_scope from Postman.
When I try to call
```csharp
string accessToken = await _tokenAcquisition.GetAccessTokenForUserAsync(_scopesToAccessDownstreamApi);
```
with either '.default' scope or one registered for internal in `_scopesToAccessDownstreamApi` I receive the exception (I'm using the Application ID URI of internal for those scopes)

**Expected behavior**
Code should work despite supported account types for which the app is registered.

**Actual behavior**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25317691/159723933-c2fa327a-3b0e-4346-89bf-4dd407fbb014.png)

**Possible solution**
<!--- Only if you have suggestions on a fix for the bug. -->

**Additional context / logs / screenshots / link to code**
<!-- Please do not include any customer data or Personal Identifiable Information (PII) in any content posted to GitHub. See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/compliance/regulatory/gdpr#gdpr-faqs for more info on PII.-->
The same code works when I use single-tenant registered apps. The only difference is in "TennantId" at appsettings.json where for this case it is set to 'common', also the URLs for authorize and token at Postman have TennantId instead of common.

The same issue is for apps registered to support only personal accounts so I'm assuming there is some issue related to provisioning the access to downstream API for tokens generated for personal accounts. 
Additionally, for those apps, I'm not able to change the status to granted, even though I'm logged in as Global Administrator.

'2022-03-28T02:15:41Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '# Is your feature request related to a problem?
My specific scenario is likely niche, but I think the capability would be broadly applicable. For context, in my case I have a web API that makes protected downstream web API calls using the `AddMicrosoftIdentityAppAuthenticationHandler` route. I chose this method over `IDownstreamApi` because I have a set of HttpClient delegating handlers (like retry and backoff policies) that vary per HttpClient type.

My specific scenario is that my downstream API has a mix of authenticated and anonymous endpoints, and the `AzureAd` config provided to each instance of my web API may be different and may have been _misconfigured by the user_. That means that if the user provides a bad configuration, all downstream API calls will fail, even the anonymous ones, because there's no `try...catch` around token acquisition in `MicrosoftIdentityAppAuthenticationMessageHandler.cs` (see https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/blob/2f465726cf62401b474243ef1805f494e95f7401/src/Microsoft.Identity.Web/DownstreamWebApiSupport/MicrosoftIdentityAppAuthenticationMessageHandler.cs#L44-L49) and thus failing to acquire a token is an uncaught exception.

# Describe the workaround you have today
Today I work around this issue by copying the entirety of `MicrosoftIdentityAppAuthenticationMessageHandler.cs` into my library to add the `try...catch`, and then additionally I need to create a new override of `AddMicrosoftIdentityAppAuthenticationHandler` with the implementation copied so that I can add my "safe" handler as the HTTP message handler (see https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/blob/2f465726cf62401b474243ef1805f494e95f7401/src/Microsoft.Identity.Web/DownstreamWebApiSupport/MicrosoftIdentityAuthenticationMessageHandlerHttpClientBuilderExtensions.cs#L97).

# Describe the solution you'd like
Depending on the level of support that makes sense for a scenario like this, I propose a tiered approach:

## Tier 1: Register and retrieve the MicrosoftIdentity*AuthenticationHandler classes from DI

If instead of calling `new` directly on the handler classes in the extension methods, if the handlers were registered as dependencies and resolved from the `ServiceCollection`, I could inherit from the handler to do my custom work, which would eliminate the need to also duplicate the extension method. Bonus points if the authentication handlers gain an interface.

## Tier 2: Move token acquisition into a virtual method in the handlers

In this tier, if we moved the token acquisition, i.e.:

```csharp
var authResult = await TokenAcquisition.GetAuthenticationResultForAppAsync(
    options.Scopes!,
    options.AuthenticationScheme,
    options.Tenant,
    options.TokenAcquisitionOptions)
    .ConfigureAwait(false);
```

into a `virtual` method, then I could override just this method and add a `try...catch`, which would avoid needing to re-implement the rest of the class.

# Describe alternatives you've considered
I added a section above with the workaround I have today. Alternatively, I could avoid the situation all together by splitting my downstream API into two different HttpClients, one for the authenticated endpoints and another for the anonymous endpoints, however in addition to having some negative performance characteristics (e.g. double TCP connections open to the same host), it also would lead to a suboptimal developer experience for my users, as the two sets of APIs aren't logically distinct, so it wouldn't be clear why some APIs use one client and some APIs use another.

Let me know if this request makes sense or not, and if you have any questions. Thanks!', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1667/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': Note that to get help, you need to run the latest version. 
Microsoft Identity Web 1.21.1

**Where is the issue?**
* Web app
    * [ ] Sign-in users
    * [ ] Sign-in users and call web APIs
* Web API
    * [ ] Protected web APIs (validating tokens)
    * [ ] Protected web APIs (validating scopes)
    * [X] Protected web APIs call downstream web APIs
* Token cache serialization
     * [ ] In-memory caches
     * [ ] Session caches
     * [ ] Distributed caches
* Other (please describe)

**Is this a new or an existing app?**
The app is in production, I have upgraded to a new version of Microsoft Identity Web in DEV environment and seen the issue.

**Repro**

```csharp
var accessToken = await this.tokenAcquisition.GetAccessTokenForAppAsync(this.auditApiScope);
```

**Expected behavior**
I would expect to get a token and I do ghet a token using versions 1.11.0 to 1.16.0

**Actual behavior**
On versions from 1.16.1 to 1.12.1 I get MsalClientException 

> IDW10104: Both client secret and client certificate cannot be null or whitespace, and only ONE must be included in the configuration of the web app when calling a web API. For instance, in the appsettings.json file.


**Possible solution**
My current workaround is to keep my version to 1.16.0

**Additional context / logs / screenshots / link to code**
I originally raised this as a Stackoverflow question, [MsalClientException IDW10104 from GetAccessTokenForAppAsync](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/71600292/msalclientexception-idw10104-from-getaccesstokenforappasync) I have since answered the question explaining that the issue only came in at 1.16.1. Note the use of `ForwardDefaultSelector ` to get rid of all the extraneous exceptions.', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1668/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1668/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/comments/1080099058', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1668#issuecomment-1080099058', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1668', 'id': 1080099058, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDODmEq2c5AYQDy', 'user': {'login': 'jmprieur', 'id': 13203188, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEzMjAzMTg4', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/13203188?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jmprieur', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-03-28T01:55:02Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-28T01:55:02Z', 'author_association': 'COLLABORATOR', 'body': '@[munkii](https://github.com/munkii)
I think that this is an authentication scheme issue.

you might want to:
- either define a default authentication scheme in your startup.cs
- Or use the override of GetAccessTokenForAppAsync with the authenticationScheme parameter, and use the authentication scheme for which you registrered the web API (B2CScheme).

See https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/wiki/multiple-authentication-schemes

We are, btw adding a new exception to the next version of Microsoft.Identity.Web to help with the authentication schemes', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/comments/1080099058/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'2022-03-28T01:42:28Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Hello,
we are using in our projects the latest version of Microsoft.Identity.Web. We came to an interesting challenge that I am not sure how to solve properly. Maybe you could point me in the right direction.

We are using Microsoft.Identity.Web and the IDistributedCache implementation for L2 cache targeting environment X. 
In the same project, we are using a different library that also requires an implementation of the IDistributedCache interface but with the requirement to target a different L2 cache environment Y.

Is there a way for me to pass an instance of L2 cache to Microsoft.Identity.Web without using the IDistributedCache interface? Maybe there might be a way to do it directly in the constructor AddDistributedTokenCaches() by passing some singletons? Are there other ways to register a custom L2 cache in Microsoft.Identity.Web?

And the last question related to caching. Is there a way to specify a custom implementation of L1 cache?

Thank you for your feedback,
Patrick', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1670/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1670/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/comments/1080094526', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1670#issuecomment-1080094526', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/issues/1670', 'id': 1080094526, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDODmEq2c5AYO8-', 'user': {'login': 'jmprieur', 'id': 13203188, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEzMjAzMTg4', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/13203188?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jmprieur', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-03-28T01:42:28Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-28T01:42:28Z', 'author_association': 'COLLABORATOR', 'body': '@[plamber](https://github.com/plamber). Microsoft.Identity.Web just uses directly IDistributedCache. So you cannot really have different implementations unless you inherit from IDistributedCache for your other environment, or for the distributed token cache.

You can, if you wish you can provide your own token cache adapter by doing something like: https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/blob/master/src/Microsoft.Identity.Web.TokenCache/Distributed/MsalDistributedTokenCacheAdapter.cs

but use a different interface here:
https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-identity-web/blob/855f6d4d9ffa52286fe432efeb5f25e625e0de5b/src/Microsoft.Identity.Web.TokenCache/Distributed/MsalDistributedTokenCacheAdapter.cs#L25

'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'Adding generation of accessors for claims independently of AAD token version of the token
See #1800

## Developer experience:

1. Add a using:
   ```CSharp
   using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt,
   ```

2.  In the code, on a ClaimsPrincipal or an IdentityPrincipal instance, you will get access to extension methods that retrieve the claims in the instance independently of them being long or short claims (which depends on the token version: v1.0 or v2.0 tokens). Developers will also get completion telling them if the claim is safe or not for use in authorization policies, and what privacy category they belong to
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13203188/160029772-1377405f-1a02-4c4a-9af4-0d42ab233f0a.png)

See also the description of the accessors:

[ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)

## Design
This PR a bit different from others: It uses code generation
The claims are described in **ClaimsKnowledge.tti** (Text Template Include file)
This include file is included in:
-  **ClaimTypeMapping.tt**, which generates ClaimTypeMapping.cs (which was already existing), 
-  **ClaimsTypeAccessor.tt**, which generates **ClaimsTypeAccessor.gen.cs**, which contains a partial class implementation of `ClaimsTypeAccessor`, the other partial being in **ClaimsTypeAccessor.cs**
- **ClaimsAccessorDoc.tt**, which generates [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)', 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'Adding generation of accessors for claims independently of AAD token version of the token
See #1800

## Developer experience:

1. Add a using:
   ```CSharp
   using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt,
   ```

2.  In the code, on a ClaimsPrincipal or an IdentityPrincipal instance, you will get access to extension methods that retrieve the claims in the instance independently of them being long or short claims (which depends on the token version: v1.0 or v2.0 tokens). Developers will also get completion telling them if the claim is safe or not for use in authorization policies, and what privacy category they belong to
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13203188/160029772-1377405f-1a02-4c4a-9af4-0d42ab233f0a.png)

See also the description of the accessors:

[ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)

## Design
This PR a bit different from others: It uses code generation
The claims are described in **ClaimsKnowledge.tti** (Text Template Include file)
This include file is included in:
-  **ClaimTypeMapping.tt**, which generates ClaimTypeMapping.cs (which was already existing), 
-  **ClaimsTypeAccessor.tt**, which generates **ClaimsTypeAccessor.gen.cs**, which contains a partial class implementation of `ClaimsTypeAccessor`, the other partial being in **ClaimsTypeAccessor.cs**
- **ClaimsAccessorDoc.tt**, which generates [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)', 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'Adding generation of accessors for claims independently of AAD token version of the token
See #1800

## Developer experience:

1. Add a using:
   ```CSharp
   using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt,
   ```

2.  In the code, on a ClaimsPrincipal or an IdentityPrincipal instance, you will get access to extension methods that retrieve the claims in the instance independently of them being long or short claims (which depends on the token version: v1.0 or v2.0 tokens). Developers will also get completion telling them if the claim is safe or not for use in authorization policies, and what privacy category they belong to
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13203188/160029772-1377405f-1a02-4c4a-9af4-0d42ab233f0a.png)

See also the description of the accessors:

[ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)

## Design
This PR a bit different from others: It uses code generation
The claims are described in **ClaimsKnowledge.tti** (Text Template Include file)
This include file is included in:
-  **ClaimTypeMapping.tt**, which generates ClaimTypeMapping.cs (which was already existing), 
-  **ClaimsTypeAccessor.tt**, which generates **ClaimsTypeAccessor.gen.cs**, which contains a partial class implementation of `ClaimsTypeAccessor`, the other partial being in **ClaimsTypeAccessor.cs**
- **ClaimsAccessorDoc.tt**, which generates [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)', 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'Adding generation of accessors for claims independently of AAD token version of the token See #1800 ## Developer experience: 1. Add a using: ```CSharp using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt, ``` 2. In the code, on a ClaimsPrincipal or an IdentityPrincipal instance, you will get access to extension methods that retrieve the claims in the instance independently of them being long or short claims (which depends on the token version: v1.0 or v2.0 tokens). Developers will also get completion telling them if the claim is safe or not for use in authorization policies, and what privacy category they belong to ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13203188/160029772-1377405f-1a02-4c4a-9af4-0d42ab233f0a.png) See also the description of the accessors: [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md) ## Design This PR a bit different from others: It uses code generation The claims are described in **ClaimsKnowledge.tti** (Text Template Include file) This include file is included in: - **ClaimTypeMapping.tt**, which generates ClaimTypeMapping.cs (which was already existing), - **ClaimsTypeAccessor.tt**, which generates **ClaimsTypeAccessor.gen.cs**, which contains a partial class implementation of `ClaimsTypeAccessor`, the other partial being in **ClaimsTypeAccessor.cs** - **ClaimsAccessorDoc.tt**, which generates [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)', 'https://api.github.com/users/jmprieur/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'Adding generation of accessors for claims independently of AAD token version of the token See #1800 ## Developer experience: 1. Add a using: ```CSharp using Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt, ``` 2. In the code, on a ClaimsPrincipal or an IdentityPrincipal instance, you will get access to extension methods that retrieve the claims in the instance independently of them being long or short claims (which depends on the token version: v1.0 or v2.0 tokens). Developers will also get completion telling them if the claim is safe or not for use in authorization policies, and what privacy category they belong to ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13203188/160029772-1377405f-1a02-4c4a-9af4-0d42ab233f0a.png) See also the description of the accessors: [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md) ## Design This PR a bit different from others: It uses code generation The claims are described in **ClaimsKnowledge.tti** (Text Template Include file) This include file is included in: - **ClaimTypeMapping.tt**, which generates ClaimTypeMapping.cs (which was already existing), - **ClaimsTypeAccessor.tt**, which generates **ClaimsTypeAccessor.gen.cs**, which contains a partial class implementation of `ClaimsTypeAccessor`, the other partial being in **ClaimsTypeAccessor.cs** - **ClaimsAccessorDoc.tt**, which generates [ClaimsAccessorDoc.md](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-identitymodel-extensions-for-dotnet/blob/jmprieur/ClaimsMappingImprovement/src/System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt/ClaimsAccessorsDoc.md)',
